strategicplangoal: 4 - Foster Continual Economic Growth and Vitality
title: Complete the WE Dunn Master Plan
progresscomments: Draft master plan issued for staff comments to be incorporated into final draft and consultant to prepare master plan presentation with recommendations. All comments submitted to consultant.  Consultant will finalize the Master plan and submit to the county.
description: This master plan will address short and long term capital improvement needs for the WE Dunn Water Reclamation Facility. These projects will address aged infrastructure, and modifications needed due to changes in regulatory requirements. The WEDWRF Master Plan will provide the COUNTY with an organized and prioritized plan for implementing recommended improvements to address optimization goals and rehabilitation and replacement (R&R) needs over a 20-year planning horizon (through year 2040). Key aspects of the WEDWRF master planning effort include future population/flow increases, future regulatory requirements,previous and ongoing studies, safety, vulnerability, reliability /resiliency and sustainability, assessment of existing wastewater treatment infrastructure, alternatives, and short and long-term improvements.
reasonforproject: This is as a result of an IG audit.

strategicplangoal: 4 - Foster Continual Economic Growth and Vitality
title: Complete the SCB Master Plan
progresscomments: Project on schedule.  County providing existing data to consultant.
description: The SCB AWRF Master Plan will provide the COUNTY with a dynamic, goal oriented master plan, that leverages the information from the previous and ongoing evaluations and defines a prioritized plan for improvements over a 20-year planning horizon (through year 2040) to meet the County's goals for SCBAWRF. Key aspects of the SCBAWRF master planning effort include short and long term goals, future population/flow increases, future regulatory requirements, previous and ongoing studies, safety, security, resiliency and sustainability efforts, and assessment of the existing infrastructure.See Scope of Services for complete scope.
reasonforproject: This is as a result of an IG audit.

strategicplangoal: 3 - Practice Superior Environmental Stewardship
title: PFAS legislation tracking
progresscomments: ​As of 12/10/19, NDAA passed both chambers.  However, the House is moving forward with other legislation.  On 12/04/19, EPA filed advanced notice of proposed rulemaking in the Federal Register.  EPA is soliciting information from the public as EPA considers proposing a future rule on adding certain PFAS to the list of toxic chemicals subject to reporting under section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA) and section 6607 of the Pollution Prevention Act (PPA). In this ANPRM, EPA outlines why the Agency is considering adding certain PFAS to EPCRA section 313, what listing actions are being considered, who may be required to report, the current understanding of hazard concerns for PFAS, EPA's hazard assessments on PFAS, and other information available on these chemicals. EPA is requesting comment on which, if any, PFAS should be evaluated for listing, how to list them, and what would be appropriate reporting thresholds given their persistence and bioaccumulation potential.
description: This project includes following federal legislation on Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) to ensure we actively participate in the regulatory development process. Congress continues to move forward with several bills.  EPA is requesting comment on which, if any, PFAS should be evaluated for compliance and the appropriate reporting thresholds given their persistence and bioaccumulation potential.

strategicplangoal: 1 - Create a Quality Workforce in a Positive, Supportive Organization
title: ​Train 100% of Employees in OSHA Requirements​
progresscomments: All hourly field personnel must complete the 10-hour OSHA Training Certification Course for Construction or General Industry. All supervisors, managers, and crew chiefs that oversee the hourly field personnel are required to take the 30-hour Construction or General Industry course during years 1 through 5. In the 6th year following the initial 30-hour certification, the manager, supervisor, or crew chief is required to take an 8-hour OSHA refresher course to maintain certification.
description: The initiative is on target with 73% of personnel trained. We anticipate to have an additional 20% of personnel trained in FY20. This is a five year initiative that began in 2017. The goal is to have 20% of the County field workforce trained every year. The total number of employees that needs to be trained is an ever fluctuating figure due to turnover and new hires. The required percentages for years one through three have been achieved. Training for year four (FY20) and year five (FY21) is on track.Beginning in year six, all supervisors, managers, and crew chiefs that oversee the field personnel will be required to take an 8 Hr. refresher course every five years.

strategicplangoal: 4 - Foster Continual Economic Growth and Vitality
title: SCB AWRF Master Plan
progresscomments: Initial progress meeting with B&V on Feb 5, 2020.  Project back on schedule.  Request for additional data provided 2/18/20. Scope will be revised to consider criticality and consequence of failure (In concert with other master plans). Internal staff met Mar 2, 2020 to further refine, define and add tpo the ranking priorities for the SCB Master Plan Project Drivers.  B & V provided a (5) category definition for 'Physical Condition Assessment' scoring, that looks to be able to be adapted to our evolving 'Resiliency' effort.  County provided the current list of 'Geodatabase Recommendations' built around Real Estate Management/Fleet/Parks and SOlid Waste to show the extent of the equipment attributes being identified.  Next step will be for B & V and the county to determine how this information can be assimilated into a single tracking format so there are no duplication of efforts and that this will provide useable information to all interested parties.  Next 'meeting' has not yet been scheduled.
description: Master Plan will provide the COUNTY with a 20-year planning horizon (through year 2040).  Project includes short and long term goals, future population/flow increases, and future regulatory requirements. Also considered are previous and ongoing studies, safety, security, resiliency,criticality and consequence of failure, sustainability efforts, and assessment of the existing infrastructure.
reasonforproject: This is as a result of an IG audit.

strategicplangoal: 5 - Deliver First Class Services to the Public and Our Customers
title: Develop New County Website
description: The new County website initiative is a conversion of thousands of pages of content into a content management system.It will​1.Create a mobile-friendly site.2.Create consistent user experience across the site.3.Enable website visitors to find the information they need without having to understand the County's structure.4.Provide access to information that resides on other county websites such as the Property Appraiser, Clerk, and Sheriff's sites through a multisite search.5.Distribute content creation while centralizing content review and site structure decisions.6.Make the site 100% complaint with the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).7.Update the design to make it better reflect Pinellas County as a progressive, forward-thinking local government.​​
reasonforproject: This is a mandatory or statutory requirement.

strategicplangoal: 3 - Practice Superior Environmental Stewardship
title: Develop Sustainability and Resiliency Action Plan (SRAP)
progresscomments: Since launching this initiative, a Sustainability and Resiliency Coordinator has been hired and a Leadership Committee and Action Team (LCAT) have convened to provide staff leadership of this initative​​​. The County announced the RFP for the Sustainability and Resiliency Action Plan (SRAP) on December 23, 2019.
description: The SRAP is a multi-year project to set the foundation and platform for sustainability and resiliency initiatives, planning, programs, policies, and solutions. This process will take an evidence-based, comprehensive approach to develop achievable strategic goals and objectives, measurable short to long-term actions, process integration, and decision-support tools. It will promote organizational and community-based sustainability and resiliency activities and programming in alignment with the County's Strategic Plan, structure, operations, and services. The SRAP will also prioritize the economic and social case for environmental sustainability, community resiliency, hazard mitigation, and climate change adaptation, including cost savings, economic opportunity, and self-sufficient programs.​​

strategicplangoal: 3 - Practice Superior Environmental Stewardship
title: Develop Sustainability and Resiliency Action Plan (SRAP)
progresscomments: Since launching this initiative, a Sustainability and Resiliency Coordinator has been hired and a Leadership Committee and Action Team (LCAT) have convened to provide staff leadership of this initative​​​. The County announced the RFP for the Sustainability and Resiliency Action Plan (SRAP) on December 23, 2019.
description: The SRAP is a multi-year project to set the foundation and platform for sustainability and resiliency initiatives, planning, programs, policies, and solutions. This process will take an evidence-based, comprehensive approach to develop achievable strategic goals and objectives, measurable short to long-term actions, process integration, and decision-support tools. It will promote organizational and community-based sustainability and resiliency activities and programming in alignment with the County's Strategic Plan, structure, operations, and services. The SRAP will also prioritize the economic and social case for environmental sustainability, community resiliency, hazard mitigation, and climate change adaptation, including cost savings, economic opportunity, and self-sufficient programs.​​

title: SCB AWRF Master Plan
progresscomments: Initial progress meeting with B&V on Feb 5, 2020.  Project back on schedule.  Request for additional data provided 2/18/20. Scope will be revised to consider criticality and consequence of failure (In concert with other master plans). Internal staff met Mar 2, 2020 to further refine, define and add tpo the ranking priorities for the SCB Master Plan Project Drivers.  B & V provided a (5) category definition for 'Physical Condition Assessment' scoring, that looks to be able to be adapted to our evolving 'Resiliency' effort.  County provided the current list of 'Geodatabase Recommendations' built around Real Estate Management/Fleet/Parks and Solid Waste to show the extent of the equipment attributes being identified.  Next step will be for B & V and the county to determine how this information can be assimilated into a single tracking format so there are no duplication of efforts and that this will provide useable information to all interested parties.  Next 'meeting' has not yet been scheduled.
description: Master Plan will provide the COUNTY with a 20-year planning horizon (through year 2040).  Project includes short and long term goals, future population/flow increases, and future regulatory requirements. Also considered are previous and ongoing studies, safety, security, resiliency,criticality and consequence of failure, sustainability efforts, and assessment of the existing infrastructure.

strategicplangoal: 5 - Deliver First Class Services to the Public and Our Customers
title: Develop New County Website
description: The website project is a conversion of thousands of pages of content into a content management system. It willCreate a mobile-friendly site.Create consistent user experience across the site.Enable website visitors to find the information they need without having to understand the County's structure.Provide access to information that resides on other county websites such as the Property Appraiser, Clerk, and Sheriff's sites through a multisite search.Distribute content creation while centralizing content review and site structure decisions.Make the site 100% complaint with the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).Update the design to make it better reflect Pinellas County as a progressive, forward-thinking local government.In addition, the county settled a lawsuit regarding PDF files on its website that were not ADA complaint. The settlement required new materials posted to the site to be compliant but does not require the county to make old materials complaint. These non-accessible materials, however, put the county at risk of lawsuits from other parties.

strategicplangoal: 5 - Deliver First Class Services to the Public and Our Customers
title: Promote Voluntary Code Enforcement Compliance
progresscomments: ​Code Enforcement worked with the Clerk of the Court, the County Attorney's office, other County departments, and other municipalities to promote the use of the electronic citation process. This improvement has resulted in the saving of hundreds of hours of staff time, which equates to tens of thousands of dollars saving to the County.Code Enforcement, through the budget review process, is looking to identify ways to increase administrative support to help address the increased workload due to the expanded citation process.
description: ​DRS, in particular the Code Enforcement Division, has been working to increase voluntary compliance by changing our service delivery model to focus on educating and informing our citizens. The focus is on compliance, not punitive in the form of fine collection or generating additional cases. Code Enforcement has been looking for      new and creative ways to communicate the code requirements to property      owners, in an effort to obtain voluntary compliance. From our point of      view a significant number of people that are found in violation find      themselves in that position because of not being familiar with the      regulations. Once they have been properly educated and informed about the      regulations and given an appropriate amount of time and resources they      will voluntarily comply. We are looking for ways to enhance that      education and communication.
contributors: Building and Development Review Services, County Administrator, Office of Management and Budget
reasonforproject: This is a discretionary project to improve processes.

strategicplangoal: 5 - Deliver First Class Services to the Public and Our Customers
title: Establish LOS for Park Operations and Maintenance
progresscomments: The draft level of service analysis​​ has been submitted to and reviewed with the Project Sponsors. Follow-up meetings are planned for January 2020 to develop an action plan based on sponsor feedback. Future milestone estimated completion dates are tentative pending this action plan.
description: The project purpose is to evaluate current (FY19) levels of service for Pinellas County’s Parks and Conversation Resources department and provide recommendations for establishing formal levels of service. PCR is seeking to set realistic expectations so it may better understand resource need and allocation, better communicate its narrative, and prepare for future park development more efficiently.  PCR has not analyzed levels of service this intently in recent years and will objectively review its strengths and weaknesses. Levels of service are a key aspect to the success of a department because it communicates realistic expectations to staff, leadership, the public, and the Pinellas County Board of County Commissioners (BCC) and identifies gaps where additional focus or resources are needed. Understanding PCR’s levels of service and gaps will allow the department to better measure its success in the future and create a data driven narrative.​

progresscomments: 80%-Project on hold until department receives further direction from county administration. Meetings are scheduled with the County Administrator and the County Commissioners over the next few weeks to review research before formal adoption.
description: Pinellas County currently allows for free-roaming community cats that are cared for by citizens or groups in the community. These cats are sterilized, vaccinated and ear-tipped by community partners working with PCAS. Under the proposed program, feral cats brought into Pinellas County Animal Services that are healthy, but not considered adoptable, would also be sterilized, vaccinated and ear-tipped, and then returned to their place of origin by county staff.

title: Downtown Palm Harbor Form-Based Code
progresscomments: Adoption is underway.​ Staff training has begun.
description: Redevelopment code focused on the relationships among buildings, sidewalks and streets, as well as promoting walkability. Form-Based Code guides the development and redevelopment of properties within a specific area. Compared to conventional zoning, Form-Based Code puts less emphasis on the use inside a building and more on its form and placement, location of parking, treatment of public/private spaces and other aspects. Overall, the code results in more predictable redevelopment that enhances the community’s character.

Env Mgmt is responsible for municipal coordination, working with M&C to implement public engagement and communications plan. To date, 137 or 461 easements needed have been obtained.  Easement public meetings in Indian Shores and Indian Rocks Beach are scheduled 2/18/2020 and 3/18/2020, respectivley.  First round of easements mailouts to be completed by 3/1/2020 (92 more to send out).  Second round of mailouts tentatively May 2020.  Third round of mailouts during Sept-Oct 2020.

In the County's budget, Programs are intended to [definition of programs]. Aligning budget programs with key outcomes, allows citizens, the Board of County Commissioners, administrators, and other stakeholders to connect resource decisions to specific performance outcomes.

strategicplangoal: 5 - Deliver First Class Services to the Public and Our Customers
title: Establish LOS for Park Operations and Maintenance
progresscomments: The draft level of service analysis​​ has been submitted to and reviewed with the Project Sponsors. Follow-up meetings are planned for January 2020 to develop an action plan based on sponsor feedback. Future milestone estimated completion dates are tentative pending this action plan.
description: The project purpose is to evaluate current (FY19) levels of service for Pinellas County’s Parks and Conversation Resources department and provide recommendations for establishing formal levels of service. PCR is seeking to set realistic expectations so it may better understand resource need and allocation, better communicate its narrative, and prepare for future park development more efficiently.  PCR has not analyzed levels of service this intently in recent years and will objectively review its strengths and weaknesses. Levels of service are a key aspect to the success of a department because it communicates realistic expectations to staff, leadership, the public, and the Pinellas County Board of County Commissioners (BCC) and identifies gaps where additional focus or resources are needed. Understanding PCR’s levels of service and gaps will allow the department to better measure its success in the future and create a data driven narrative.​

strategicplangoal: 4 - Foster Continual Economic Growth and Vitality
title: Downtown Palm Harbor Form-Based Code
progresscomments: Adoption is underway.​ Staff training has begun.
description: Redevelopment code focused on the relationships among buildings, sidewalks and streets, as well as promoting walkability. Form-Based Code guides the development and redevelopment of properties within a specific area. Compared to conventional zoning, Form-Based Code puts less emphasis on the use inside a building and more on its form and placement, location of parking, treatment of public/private spaces and other aspects. Overall, the code results in more predictable redevelopment that enhances the community’s character.

strategicplangoal: 3 - Practice Superior Environmental Stewardship
title: Implement the PFAS legislation amendments
progresscomments: ​As of 12/10/19, NDAA passed both chambers.  However, the House is moving forward with other legislation.  On 12/04/19, EPA filed advanced notice of proposed rulemaking in the Federal Register.  EPA is soliciting information from the public as EPA considers proposing a future rule on adding certain PFAS to the list of toxic chemicals subject to reporting under section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA) and section 6607 of the Pollution Prevention Act (PPA). In this ANPRM, EPA outlines why the Agency is considering adding certain PFAS to EPCRA section 313, what listing actions are being considered, who may be required to report, the current understanding of hazard concerns for PFAS, EPA's hazard assessments on PFAS, and other information available on these chemicals. EPA is requesting comment on which, if any, PFAS should be evaluated for listing, how to list them, and what would be appropriate reporting thresholds given their persistence and bioaccumulation potential.
description: This project includes following federal legislation on Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) to ensure we actively participate in the regulatory development process. Congress continues to move forward with several bills.  EPA is requesting comment on which, if any, PFAS should be evaluated for compliance and the appropriate reporting thresholds given their persistence and bioaccumulation potential.

strategicplangoal: 2 - Ensure Public Health, Safety, and Welfare
title: Insurance Processing
progresscomments: 3/31/2020 MK In cooperation with Records Management and Clerk's IT, the Department introduced a game-changing process improvement to capture electronic insurance certificates in .pdf form directly into AppXtender. This initiative has made significant improvements in the processing time for and backlog ​of insurance certificates and is expected to generate savings of $30,000 per year in IntergovernmentalAllocations for imaging services no longer required from Records Management.The benefit of this process improvement will be seen in FY22 for efficiencies realizedin FY20.The priority for FY20 Q2 is to work with OTI to automate expiration notices, effect automatic suspensions upon expiry of insurance, assign fees and penalties and allow for the payment of those fees and penalties online.
description: In addition to registering contractors, the PCCLB monitorslicensed contractors’ insurance coverage to confirm proof of valid liabilityand workers’ compensation insurance (or exemption from workers' compensation) to reduce risk to consumersand protect workers.We renew and administer licenses for more than 13,000contractors, each of whom has at least one insurance renewal certificate everyyear.  Overseeing insurance certificatesis still largely a manual process.Continuous process improvements have made significantand measurable results in efficiency. The goal is to implement technologysolutions to eliminate the backlog, automate manual processes and move to acontractor self-service model.
contributors: Clerk of the Circuit Court, Office of Technology & Innovation (OTI)
reasonforproject: This is a discretionary project to improve processes.

strategicplangoal: 5 - Deliver First Class Services to the Public and Our Customers
title: Develop Countywide and Departmental Work plans
description: This initiative aims to develop a framework and implementation plan for preparing a Countywide as well as department work plans and initiating regular progress reporting. Pinellas County is responsible to the Board of County Commissioners, the public, and other stakeholders for the overall performance of the County’s programs and initiatives. To have the intended impact, County staff need to establish clear desired outcomes for initiatives and communicate effectively regarding progress toward those outcomes. Work plans, in combination with data reporting, performance dashboards, and management meetings, are important tools for communicating needs, priorities, and progress within and between County departments, helping staff to plan, manage, and communicate initiatives. Likewise, a Countywide work plan that includes initiatives of Countywide significance and involving multiple county agencies, helps keep the Board and the public apprised of progress and next steps. Once these are completed, interdepartmental communication will be enhanced.

strategicplangoal: 2 - Ensure Public Health, Safety, and Welfare
title: Health in All Policies (HiAP)
progresscomments: Develop cross sector relationships HiAP working group and HiAP collaborative is complete. Enhance workforce capacity is approximately 50% complete. Incorporate health into decision-making processes is about 50% complete (sub-task of Complete a Health Impact Assessment is nearly completed)
description: Health in All Policies (HiAP) is a collaborative approach to improving the health of all people by incorporating health considerations into decision-making across sectors and policy areas. To improve health and equity, community partners came together to form the HiAP Pinellas County Collaborative. Partners include Pinellas County Government, the City of Pinellas Park, the City of St. Petersburg, the Florida Department of Health in Pinellas County, Forward Pinellas, and the Foundation for a Healthy St. Petersburg. Through collaboration, policy change, and institutional transformation, the HiAP Collaborative aims to make the healthy choice the most easily accessible choice for all Pinellas County citizens.
contributors: County Administrator, Office of Management and Budget, Public Works

title: Implement the AMI Meter contract
progresscomments: The decision to draft the RFP internally and not utilize outside consultancy was made on March 27th. The draft RFP Technical Specifications and Scope of work is 97% complete. A meeting with the Customer Service and Maintenance Division Directors is scheduled for 4/17/2020. This meeting objectives will be to go over the RFP structure and approach for the contract and to review and agree upon key performance standards, criteria and requirements. In preperation for submittal of the RFP, the Purchasing Project Funding and Request Form for Advertisement of CCNA are being prepared.
description: Implementation of the AMI Meter Reading Network will enhance data collection and provide the customer with a more accurate bill.  It will also enhance and provide PCU staff a safer environment as it relates to collecting meter data since they do not have to walk from place to place.  The AMI project will allow PCU to offer monthly billing, better manage system-wide water usage, provide water use informaton to customers, earlier leak detection, quantify water loss and provide savings from implementing automatic turn on/off reads.
reasonforproject: This is a discretionary project to improve processes.

strategicplangoal: 4 - Foster Continual Economic Growth and Vitality
title: Downtown Palm Harbor Form-Based Code
progresscomments: Still in progress.  Has 2 hearings before the BCC which were pushed out due to COVID. Put on hold until another related project has gone through it's BCC hearing cycle.First hearing with BCC in June 23, 2020. After this hearing, the other project will need to finish it's hearing cycle.Corresponding project has to go the the state for review so this end date is not in County control.
description: Redevelopment code focused on the relationships among buildings, sidewalks and streets, as well as promoting walkability. Form-Based Code guides the development and redevelopment of properties within a specific area. Compared to conventional zoning, Form-Based Code puts less emphasis on the use inside a building and more on its form and placement, location of parking, treatment of public/private spaces and other aspects. Overall, the code results in more predictable redevelopment that enhances the community’s character.

strategicplangoal: 5 - Deliver First Class Services to the Public and Our Customers
title: Establish LOS for Park Operations and Maintenance
progresscomments: The draft level of service analysis​​ has been submitted to and reviewed with the Project Sponsors. Follow-up meetings are planned for January 2020 to develop an action plan based on sponsor feedback. Future milestone estimated completion dates are tentative pending this action plan.
description: The purpose this initiative is to evaluate current (FY19) levels of service for Pinellas County’s Parks and Conversation Resources department and provide recommendations for establishing formal levels of service. PCR is seeking to set realistic expectations so it may better understand resource need and allocation, better communicate its narrative, and prepare for future park development more efficiently. PCR has not analyzed levels of service this intently in recent years and will objectively review its strengths and weaknesses. Levels of service are a key aspect to the success of a department because it communicates realistic expectations to staff, leadership, the public, and the Pinellas County Board of County Commissioners (BCC) and identifies gaps where additional focus or resources are needed. Understanding PCR’s levels of service and gaps will allow the department to better measure its success in the future and create a data driven narrative.​​

title: Create a Mobile Home Park Improvement Strategy
progresscomments: ​The Scope of Work and Strategy kick-off is nearly complete (95%). The DRAFT Strategy Recommendations Development is about 10% complete.
description: The Manufactured Housing Strategy identifies guiding principles and a prioritized list of actions to further the Pinellas County Comprehensive Plan (PCCP) and Affordable Housing Strategy. Recognizing the importance of manufactured housing as an option for many households, the County desires policies and programs toencourage the preservation of existing manufactured home parks, the development of new manufactured home parks including increasing opportunities for resident-owned parks; andreduce or eliminate health and safety issues, and mitigate displacement and loss of housing. Strategies discussed ultimately must balance the needs of manufactured home owners/tenants, with the interests of park owners, and the feasibility of administration.

strategicplangoal: 5 - Deliver First Class Services to the Public and Our Customers
title: Voluntary Code Enforcement Compliance
progresscomments: ​Code Enforcement worked with the Clerk of the Court, the County Attorney's office, other County departments, and other municipalities to promote the use of the electronic citation process. This improvement has resulted in the saving of hundreds of hours of staff time, which equates to tens of thousands of dollars saving to the County.
description: ​DRS, in particular the Code Enforcement Division, has been working to increase voluntary compliance by changing our service delivery model to focus on educating and informing our citizens. The focus is on compliance, not punitive in the form of fine collection or generating additional cases. Code Enforcement has been looking for      new and creative ways to communicate the code requirements to property      owners, in an effort to obtain voluntary compliance. From our point of      view a significant number of people that are found in violation find      themselves in that position because of not being familiar with the      regulations. Once they have been properly educated and informed about the      regulations and given an appropriate amount of time and resources they      will voluntarily comply. We are looking for ways to enhance that      education and communication.
reasonforproject: This is a discretionary project to improve processes.

Residents are interested in seeing a theme that involves "Unity" and/or children. The artists will begin painting in August.​​06.03.20 - The mural artists are scheduled to begin painting this summer. A Zoom meeting will be held on June 11 with the artist to garner community input on the wall design located on the corner of Belcher Road at Alderman Road. 04.28.20 - Pending project timeline update from Creative Pinellas, which will be reflected in work plan.04.9.20 - Delayed meeting to select artists based on COVID-19.  The review panel selection committee met on 4/9/2020 via video conference and selected three artists, one for each of the mural wall locations. Infrastructure has been prepared by Roadway Section.02.12.20 - The call for interested aritst was released in early February, once interested candidates submit an application they will be reviewed by Creative Pinellas and Public Works Transportation staff to select an artist for each of the three murals. ​
description: Support vibrant communities with art and culture. Three locations were selected for the FY20 Mural Art Program. These locatins include(1) Eastlake Road South of Keystone Road, Tarpon Springs(2) Southeast Corner of Belcher Road at Alderman Road, Palm Harbor(3) Belcher Road, North of Alderman Road, Palm Harbor A pilot program was done in FY19. A similar funding amount is available for FY20 but Creative Pinellas would like to discuss other opportunities for public art including County buildings, signal cabinets and other potential areas like parks.

strategicplangoal: 1 - Create a Quality Workforce in a Positive, Supportive Organization
title: ​Train 100% of Employees in OSHA Requirements​
progresscomments: All hourly field personnel must complete the 10-hour OSHA Training Certification Course for Construction or General Industry. All supervisors, managers, and crew chiefs that oversee the hourly field personnel are required to take the 30-hour Construction or General Industry course during years 1 through 5. In the 6th year following the initial 30-hour certification, the manager, supervisor, or crew chief is required to take an 8-hour OSHA refresher course to maintain certification.
description: Federal OSHA regulations impacting County employees are expected to take effect in the years to come. All hourly field personnel must complete the 10-hour OSHA Training Certification Course for Construction or General Industry. All supervisors, managers, and crew chiefs that oversee the hourly field personnel are required to take the 30-hour Construction or General Industry course during years 1 through 5.

strategicplangoal: 5 - Deliver First Class Services to the Public and Our Customers
title: Promote Voluntary Code Enforcement Compliance
progresscomments: ​Code Enforcement worked with the Clerk of the Court, the County Attorney's office, other County departments, and other municipalities to promote the use of the electronic citation process. This improvement has resulted in the saving of hundreds of hours of staff time, which equates to tens of thousands of dollars saving to the County.
description: ​DRS, in particular the Code Enforcement Division, has been working to increase voluntary compliance by changing our service delivery model to focus on educating and informing our citizens. The focus is on compliance, not punitive in the form of fine collection or generating additional cases. Code Enforcement has been looking for      new and creative ways to communicate the code requirements to property      owners, in an effort to obtain voluntary compliance. From our point of      view a significant number of people that are found in violation find      themselves in that position because of not being familiar with the      regulations. Once they have been properly educated and informed about the      regulations and given an appropriate amount of time and resources they      will voluntarily comply. We are looking for ways to enhance that      education and communication.
reasonforproject: This is a discretionary project to improve processes.

strategicplangoal: 2 - Ensure Public Health, Safety, and Welfare
title: Health in All Policies (HiAP)
progresscomments: Project ongoing related to the grant. Just renewed annual grant contract which ends December 2020. Integrating into multiple related projects. Not necessarily a project - Caitlin is the grant. End date will be pushed out if the contract is renewed.
description: Health in All Policies (HiAP) is a collaborative approach to improving the health of all people by incorporating health considerations into decision-making across sectors and policy areas. To improve health and equity, community partners came together to form the HiAP Pinellas County Collaborative. Partners include Pinellas County Government, the City of Pinellas Park, the City of St. Petersburg, the Florida Department of Health in Pinellas County, Forward Pinellas, and the Foundation for a Healthy St. Petersburg. Through collaboration, policy change, and institutional transformation, the HiAP Collaborative aims to make the healthy choice the most easily accessible choice for all Pinellas County citizens.
contributors: County Administrator, Office of Management and Budget, Public Works

strategicplangoal: 4 - Foster Continual Economic Growth and Vitality
title: Mobile Home Park Improvement Strategy
progresscomments: ​The Scope of Work and Strategy kick-off is nearly complete (95%). The DRAFT Strategy Recommendations Development is about 10% complete.
description: The Manufactured Housing Strategy identifies guiding principles and a prioritized list of actions to further the Pinellas County Comprehensive Plan (PCCP) and Affordable Housing Strategy. Recognizing the importance of manufactured housing as an option for many households, the County desires policies and programs toencourage the preservation of existing manufactured home parks, the development of new manufactured home parks including increasing opportunities for resident-owned parks; andreduce or eliminate health and safety issues, and mitigate displacement and loss of housing. Strategies discussed ultimately must balance the needs of manufactured home owners/tenants, with the interests of park owners, and the feasibility of administration.

Recognizing the importance of manufactured housing as an option for many households, the County desires policies and programs toencourage the preservation of existing manufactured home parks, the development of new manufactured home parks including increasing opportunities for resident-owned parks; andreduce or eliminate health and safety issues, and mitigate displacement and loss of housing. Strategies discussed ultimately must balance the needs of manufactured home owners/tenants, with the interests of park owners, and the feasibility of administration.

strategicplangoal: 2 - Ensure Public Health, Safety, and Welfare
title: Classification Review (Specialty Licenses)
progresscomments: 03/31/2020 MK The Department has identified 17 Classifications that are duplicates, abandoned, retired (but still tracking) or recommended for retirement. Additionally, the Department recommends elimination of the County-only Awning Specialty and the Painting Limited Specialty classifications.  After all of the changes noted are implemented, the County is projected to oversee 21 County-only classifications, 5 existing County-level Journeyman classifications and 37 State/County classifications for a total of 63 (from 87). Changes are proposed to take effect as of 9/30/2020.03/31/2020 MK Second Classification Review (Carpentry, Finish Carpentry, Cabinet and Flooring) in progress. Consultations with the contractor community are underway. Recommendations for changes to add a new Flooring classification are being defined. Plans to present initial findings to the PCCLB Board at the 3/17/2020 meeting have been interrupted by COVID-19. 12/9/2019 MK First Classification Review (Swimming Pool/Spa specialty contractors) completed at 11/19/2019 PCCLB Board meeting.  Next on the agenda for the Department/Board is the existing Carpentry, Finish Carpentry, and Cabinetry Classifications. The Department is also reviewing a request to incorporate a requirement for flooring (not tile) contractors.  The Department has invited BDRS and Consumer Protection (in addition to other municipalities and county building/licensing departments) to participate in classification review.​
description: TheContractor Licensing Department is undertaking a review of specialty licensesin order to make recommendations in consultation with the Board to refine,eliminate or confirm license Classifications. As of January 1, 2020, there were 87 Classifications onrecord with PCCLB. This class list has been compiled from a number of sources,validated against the PCCLB Rules, the PCCLB Oracle D2K app, and the FloridaDepartment of Business and Professional Regulation (DBPR).Each review will followsimilar steps to evaluate the priority, requirements, risks and impact oncitizens, businesses, business owners, the environment and other stakeholdersin the community. As of January 1, 2020, the County issued licenses in 22 classifications at the County level only (not required at the State level). All other license classifications are synchronized with the State.
contributors: Building and Development Review Services, Human Services
reasonforproject: This is a discretionary project to improve processes.

description: The Highpoint Community Action Plan (CAP) serves two distinct purposes. First, it is a short-range strategic document that sets forth practical goals and specific actions that facilitates the preservation and improvement of the community. Secondly, it establishes specific actions that County departments agree to take to assist in achieving the goals. The process provides a framework for the community and partners to address issues through a step-by-step action plan that becomes a monitoring resource to ensure the actions are moving forward.

strategicplangoal: 3 - Practice Superior Environmental Stewardship
title: Implement the PFAS legislation amendments
progresscomments: ​As of 12/10/19, NDAA passed both chambers.  However, the House is moving forward with other legislation.  On 12/04/19, EPA filed advanced notice of proposed rulemaking in the Federal Register.  EPA is soliciting information from the public as EPA considers proposing a future rule on adding certain PFAS to the list of toxic chemicals subject to reporting under section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA) and section 6607 of the Pollution Prevention Act (PPA). In this ANPRM, EPA outlines why the Agency is considering adding certain PFAS to EPCRA section 313, what listing actions are being considered, who may be required to report, the current understanding of hazard concerns for PFAS, EPA's hazard assessments on PFAS, and other information available on these chemicals. EPA is requesting comment on which, if any, PFAS should be evaluated for listing, how to list them, and what would be appropriate reporting thresholds given their persistence and bioaccumulation potential.
description: This project includes following federal legislation on Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) to ensure we actively participate in the regulatory development process. Congress continues to move forward with several bills.  EPA is requesting comment on which, if any, PFAS should be evaluated for compliance and the appropriate reporting thresholds given their persistence and bioaccumulation potential.

strategicplangoal: 5 - Deliver First Class Services to the Public and Our Customers
title: Develop a Countywide and departmental work plans
description: This initiative aims to develop a framework and implementation plan for preparing a Countywide as well as department work plans and initiating regular progress reporting. Pinellas County is responsible to the Board of County Commissioners, the public, and other stakeholders for the overall performance of the County’s programs and initiatives. To have the intended impact, County staff need to establish clear desired outcomes for initiatives and communicate effectively regarding progress toward those outcomes. Work plans, in combination with data reporting, performance dashboards, and management meetings, are important tools for communicating needs, priorities, and progress within and between County departments, helping staff to plan, manage, and communicate initiatives. Likewise, a Countywide work plan that includes initiatives of Countywide significance and involving multiple county agencies, helps keep the Board and the public apprised of progress and next steps. Once these are completed, interdepartmental communication will be enhanced.

strategicplangoal: 2 - Ensure Public Health, Safety, and Welfare
title: Classification Review (Specialty Licenses)
progresscomments: 04/23/2020 MK Next classification review Paving. The Department will survey municipal and County Building Departments for input, opinions and risks associated with the possible elimination of the Paving Specialty.03/31/2020 MK The Department has identified 17 Classifications that are duplicates, abandoned, retired (but still tracking) or recommended for retirement. Additionally, the Department recommends elimination of the County-only Awning Specialty and the Painting Limited Specialty classifications.  After all of the changes noted are implemented, the County is projected to oversee 20 County-only classifications, 5 existing County-level Journeyman classifications and 37 State/County classifications for a total of 63 (from 87). Changes are proposed to take effect as of 9/30/2020.03/31/2020 MK Second Classification Review (Carpentry, Finish Carpentry, Cabinet and Flooring) in progress. Consultations with the contractor community are underway. Recommendations for changes to add a new Flooring classification are being defined. Plans to present initial findings to the PCCLB Board at the 3/17/2020 meeting have been interrupted by COVID-19. 12/9/2019 MK First Classification Review (Swimming Pool/Spa specialty contractors) completed at 11/19/2019 PCCLB Board meeting.  Next on the agenda for the Department/Board is the existing Carpentry, Finish Carpentry, and Cabinetry Classifications. The Department is also reviewing a request to incorporate a requirement for flooring (not tile) contractors.  The Department has invited BDRS and Consumer Protection (in addition to other municipalities and county building/licensing departments) to participate in classification review.​
description: TheContractor Licensing Department is undertaking a review of specialty licensesin order to make recommendations in consultation with the Board to refine,eliminate or confirm license Classifications. As of January 1, 2020, there were 87 Classifications onrecord with PCCLB. This class list has been compiled from a number of sources,validated against the PCCLB Rules, the PCCLB Oracle D2K app, and the FloridaDepartment of Business and Professional Regulation (DBPR).Each review will followsimilar steps to evaluate the priority, requirements, risks and impact oncitizens, businesses, business owners, the environment and other stakeholdersin the community. As of January 1, 2020, the County issued licenses in 22 classifications at the County level only (not required at the State level). All other license classifications are managed by and synchronized with the State.
contributors: Building and Development Review Services, Human Services
reasonforproject: This is a discretionary project to improve processes.

strategicplangoal: 5 - Deliver First Class Services to the Public and Our Customers
title: Establish LOS for Park Operations and Maintenance
progresscomments: The draft level of service analysis​​ has been submitted to and reviewed with the Project Sponsors. Follow-up meetings are planned for January 2020 to develop an action plan based on sponsor feedback. Future milestone estimated completion dates are tentative pending this action plan.
description: The project purpose is to evaluate current (FY19) levels of service for Pinellas County’s Parks and Conversation Resources department and provide recommendations for establishing formal levels of service. PCR is seeking to set realistic expectations so it may better understand resource need and allocation, better communicate its narrative, and prepare for future park development more efficiently.  PCR has not analyzed levels of service this intently in recent years and will objectively review its strengths and weaknesses. Levels of service are a key aspect to the success of a department because it communicates realistic expectations to staff, leadership, the public, and the Pinellas County Board of County Commissioners (BCC) and identifies gaps where additional focus or resources are needed. Understanding PCR’s levels of service and gaps will allow the department to better measure its success in the future and create a data driven narrative.​

strategicplangoal: 5 - Deliver First Class Services to the Public and Our Customers
title: Develop New County Website
description: The new County website initiative is a conversion of thousands of pages of content into a content management system.It will​1.Create a mobile-friendly site.2.Create consistent user experience across the site.3.Enable website visitors to find the information they need without having to understand the County's structure.4.Provide access to information that resides on other county websites such as the Property Appraiser, Clerk, and Sheriff's sites through a multisite search.5.Distribute content creation while centralizing content review and site structure decisions.6.Make the site 100% complaint with the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).7.Update the design to make it better reflect Pinellas County as a progressive, forward-thinking local government.​​
reasonforproject: This is a mandatory or statutory requirement.

progresscomments: ​The pilot program has been development and implemented. Staff has been processing cases through the settlement process, including use of the Hardship Committee. We have also discussed modificatoins to the program with our Assistant County Administrator. These items will be incorporated in to a draft ordinance and brought to the County Administrator for consideration before being scheduled to go to the BCC.This item has been delayed because of the County's COVID 19 response efforts. This matter is not considered essential, so the scheduling of this item on the BCC calendar has been postponed.
description: The lien      settlement program is how best to address the high volume of liens and      lien amounts that have been allowed to accrue over the years. The goal      is, like that of the foreclosure process, to return these properties back      into contributing assets for the community.
contributors: Building and Development Review Services, County Administrator, County Attorney

strategicplangoal: 1 - Create a Quality Workforce in a Positive, Supportive Organization
title: Clarify Budget and Financial Services Roles
description: The purpose of this initiative is to review, clarify, and define budget andfinancial services roles and provide recommendations in order to support a clear understanding of rolesand responsibilities by both OMB and departmental staff;aninformed decision-making process around possible future realignments of budgetand financial services; and the development of clear, long-term strategy/visionaround budget and financial services. The scope of this initative is limited to budget and financial management servicesresponsibilities for County Administrator departments. Not included in thescope are core budget formulation and publication tasks (e.g. – TRIMcompliance; coordination, formulation, and production of total County budgetand Capital Improvement Plan; analysis of budget requests) nor budget and financialmanagement service roles for departments and agencies that do not report to theCounty Administrator. The following items are included in Budget and FinancialManagement Services Procure-to-Pay; Accounts Receivable; Account StringMaintenance; Budget Preparation, Analysis, and Monitoring on an individualdepartment basis; Contract/Agreement Development; Financial Reporting; Grants Administrationand Support; Financial Analysis; and Technical Assistance for budget and accountingsoftware(s).Initiative Files
reasonforproject: This is a discretionary project to improve processes.

A very conservative assumption was made to total the value of projects that would contribute to the NSPS threshold.  This estimate included boiler projects that are scheduled to be completed during calendar year 2021 and an additional future project.  It was determined that the value of the projects was less than the NSPS criteria.  With no significant qualifying projects currently planned, the next Update will be scheduled in 5 years or calendar year 2026.
description: Monitor NSPS compliance and coordinate with consultants for options

strategicplangoal: 4 - Foster Continual Economic Growth and Vitality
title: Highpoint Community Action Plan
progresscomments: 09/25/2020 - Caroline Lanford has created a draft list of potential projects for implementation. These are being vetted by Public Works.​Next steps will include developing a scope of work to complete a more comprehensive strategy. ​12/10/2020 - We are coordinating with Brian Lowack to determine the next steps in this project.
description: The Highpoint Community Action Plan (CAP) serves two distinct purposes. First, it is a short-range strategic document that sets forth practical goals and specific actions that facilitates the preservation and improvement of the community. Secondly, it establishes specific actions that County departments agree to take to assist in achieving the goals. The process provides a framework for the community and partners to address issues through a step-by-step action plan that becomes a monitoring resource to ensure the actions are moving forward.

strategicplangoal: 3 - Practice Superior Environmental Stewardship
title: Expand Bulky Waste Processing
progresscomments: Loads  of waste delivered to the Complex may include oversized items which cannot be  processed at the WTE due to their size restrictions.  The County could develop full scale bulky  waste processing capability at the Complex, either through a public/ private  partnership or through design and acquisition of the appropriate equipment  and operating facility. This type of system would result in more diversion of  materials from the landfill, improved operation of the WTE and improved  compaction of materials in the landfill by their removal from the landfilled  waste stream, due to the size reduction of hard-to-manage items such as  mattresses and furniture.
description: Extend  Landfill Life by Expanding Bulky Waste Processing

strategicplangoal: 3 - Practice Superior Environmental Stewardship
title: Implement Sand Key easement acquisition program
progresscomments: The acquisition of easements along Sand Key is required to ensure commitment of federal funding for nourishment. Survey is overseeing the research side of the process and easement document preparation. Env Mgmt is responsible for municipal coordination, working with M&C to implement public engagement and communications plan. To date, 221 of 461 easements needed (~47.9%) have been obtained. A public easement meeting was held Sept 23, ​2020 as a virtual meeting.  The first and second sets of easements have been mailed out.  The third set mailout is scheduled for Feb. 2021. The County has until the end of FY21 to provide the easements or the Sand Key nourishment will be postponed until this requirement is met.  ​
description: Implement the easement acquistion program to facilitate acquistion of 461 easements from beach property owners along Sand Key as required by the Army Corps of Enginners.  All easements are needed by Spring 2021 for the next nourishment project tentatively planned for 2023-2024.
contributors: County Attorney, Marketing and Communications, Public Works

strategicplangoal: 1 - Create a Quality Workforce in a Positive, Supportive Organization
title: ​Train 100% of Employees in OSHA Requirements​
progresscomments: All hourly field personnel must complete the 10-hour OSHA Training Certification Course for Construction or General Industry. All supervisors, managers, and crew chiefs that oversee the hourly field personnel are required to take the 30-hour Construction or General Industry course during years 1 through 5. In the 6th year following the initial 30-hour certification, the manager, supervisor, or crew chief is required to take an 8-hour OSHA refresher course to maintain certification.
description: The initiative is on target with 73% of personnel trained. We anticipate to have an additional 20% of personnel trained in FY20. This is a five year initiative that began in 2017. The goal is to have 20% of the County field workforce trained every year. The total number of employees that needs to be trained is an ever fluctuating figure due to turnover and new hires. The required percentages for years one through three have been achieved. Training for year four (FY20) and year five (FY21) is on track.Beginning in year six, all supervisors, managers, and crew chiefs that oversee the field personnel will be required to take an 8 Hr. refresher course every five years.

title: Implement the AMI Meter contract
progresscomments: The decision to draft the RFP internally and not utilize outside consultancy was made on March 27th. The draft RFP Technical Specifications and Scope of work is 97% complete. A meeting with the Customer Service and Maintenance Division Directors is scheduled for 4/17/2020. This meeting objectives will be to go over the RFP structure and approach for the contract and to review and agree upon key performance standards, criteria and requirements. In preperation for submittal of the RFP, the Purchasing Project Funding and Request Form for Advertisement of CCNA are being prepared.
description: Implementation of the AMI Meter Reading Network will enhance data collection and provide the customer with a more accurate bill.  It will also enhance and provide PCU staff a safer environment as it relates to collecting meter data since they do not have to walk from place to place.  The AMI project will allow PCU to offer monthly billing, better manage system-wide water usage, provide water use informaton to customers, earlier leak detection, quantify water loss and provide savings from implementing automatic turn on/off reads.
reasonforproject: This is a discretionary project to improve processes.

strategicplangoal: 4 - Foster Continual Economic Growth and Vitality
title: Implement Land Development Code
progresscomments: Staff has been reviewing the LDC chapters for suggested edits. The edits have been segmented into near-term responses (1-3 month), mid-term (3-6 months) and long-term (over 6 months).Staff is now compiling a list of the near-term items that can be vetted and then brought to the BCC for consideration.This process is still underway, but has experienced some delays due to workload impacts resulting from the COVID 19 response. Suggested edits for Affordable housing have been brought forward to the DCAG. The SSC has review suggestions regarding Chapters 138 and 154.Additionally we are working on suggested edits to the landscaping section in 138 and the habitat section in Chapter 166,
description: Revisions      to the LDC were adopted in October 2018 and became effective in January      2019. Since that time staff has been going through extensive training so      that they are a proficient and efficient as possible when assisting our      customers. We continue to look for ways to effectively communicate the      zoning regulations to a customer base that does not utilize these      regulations on a routine basis.
contributors: Airport, Building and Development Review Services, Planning, Public Works

strategicplangoal: 3 - Practice Superior Environmental Stewardship
title: PFAS legislation tracking
progresscomments: ​On 12/04/19, EPA filed advanced notice of proposed rulemaking in the Federal Register.  EPA is soliciting information from the public as EPA considers proposing a future rule on adding certain PFAS to the list of toxic chemicals subject to reporting under section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA) and section 6607 of the Pollution Prevention Act (PPA). In this ANPRM, EPA outlines why the Agency is considering adding certain PFAS to EPCRA section 313, what listing actions are being considered, who may be required to report, the current understanding of hazard concerns for PFAS, EPA's hazard assessments on PFAS, and other information available on these chemicals. EPA is requesting comment on which, if any, PFAS should be evaluated for listing, how to list them, and what would be appropriate reporting thresholds given their persistence and bioaccumulation potential.
description: This project includes following federal legislation on Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) to ensure we actively participate in the regulatory development process. Congress continues to move forward with several bills.  EPA is requesting comment on which, if any, PFAS should be evaluated for compliance and the appropriate reporting thresholds given their persistence and bioaccumulation potential.
